datafield.subfield: Vivian Fine was an American composer, pianist, and educator. The collection primarily consists of Fine's holograph manuscript scores, sketches, and parts for works composed between 1929 and 1993. In addition, the collection contains a small amount of correspondence, programs, and clippings.

titlestmt.author: Processed by the Music Division of the Library of Congress

seriesstmt.titleproper: Guides to Special Collections in the Music Division of the Library of Congress

profiledesc.creation: Finding aid encoded by Library of Congress Music Division, 2011

did.head: Collection Summary
did.abstract: Vivian Fine was an American composer, pianist, and educator. The collection primarily consists of Fine's holograph manuscript scores, sketches, and parts for works composed between 1929 and 1993. In addition, the collection contains a small amount of correspondence, programs, and clippings.

note.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the Library's online catalog. They are grouped by name of person or organization, by subject or location, and by occupation and listed alphabetically therein.

processinfo.head: Processing History
processinfo.p: The Vivian Fine Music Manuscripts were processed by Thomas Barrick in 2011. Thomas Barrick coded the finding aid for EAD format in 2011.

separatedmaterial.head: Transfers
separatedmaterial.p: Sound recordings have been transferred to the Library of Congress Motion Picture, Broadcasting and Recorded Sound Division where they are identified as part of the Vivian Fine Collection (Library of Congress). An inventory of these recordings is available in the Library of Congress Music Division collection file.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: The Library of Congress Music Division holds several collections that contain materials, such as correspondence and music, relating to Fine and her work. They are the Aaron Copland Collection; Nicolas Slonimsky Collection; Jacobo Ficher Collection; Herman Langinger Music Publishing Files; Artur Rodzinski Collection; and the Martha Graham Collection. Fine's holograph score for Poetic Fires (ML30.3c.F554 no. 1 <case>) is located in the Serge Koussevitzky Music Foundation Collection and Ode to Henry Purcell (ML29c.F528 no. 1 <case>) is located in the Elizabeth Sprague Coolidge Foundation Collection.

userestrict.head: Copyright Status
userestrict.p: Materials from the Vivian Fine Music Manuscripts are governed by the Copyright Law of the United States (Title 17, U.S.C.) and other applicable international copyright laws.

accessrestrict.head: Access and Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: The Vivian Fine Music Manuscripts are open to research. Researchers are advised to contact the Music Division prior to visiting in order to determine whether the desired materials will be available at that time.
Certain restrictions to use or copying of materials may apply.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Researchers wishing to cite this collection should include the following information: [item, date, container number], Vivian Fine Music Manuscripts, Music Division, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

chronitem.event: Born, Chicago, to Russian-Jewish immigrants Rose and David Fine

eventgrp.event: Became youngest student ever to receive a scholarship from the Chicago Musical College

chronitem.event: Studied piano with Djane Lavoie-Herz, former student of Scriabin
Composed first work, Lullaby, for piano

eventgrp.event: Studied harmony and composition with Ruth Crawford and counterpoint with Adolf Weidig at American Conservatory in Chicago
Met Henry Cowell, Dane Rudhyar, and Imre Weisshauss, who became early supporters

chronitem.event: Solo for Oboe premiered at Carnegie Hall

eventgrp.event: Dance accompanist, Gluck-Sandor Dance Theater and other studios
Became member of Aaron Copland's Young Composers' Group
Premiere of Four Polyphonic Pieces for Piano at the First Yaddo Festival

chronitem.event: Helped found The American Composers' Alliance
Faculty member, piano department, New York University, New York, N.Y.

eventgrp.event: Adjunct faculty member, literature and materials, Juilliard School, New York, N.Y.
Moved to New Paltz, New York

chronitem.event: Teacher, composition, Bennington College, Bennington, Vt.
Elected to the American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Vivian Fine Music Manuscripts chiefly consist of holograph scores, sketches, and parts for works written between 1929 and 1993. Fine's compositions spanned a variety of musical genres: solo instrumental, chamber, orchestral, as well as accompanied vocal and choral pieces. Notable compositions include Capriccio for Oboe and String Trio (1946), The Great Wall of China (1946), Fine's collaboration with Martha Graham, Alcestis (1960), and chamber operas The Women in the Garden (1978) and Memoirs of Uliana Rooney (1994). A small quantity of correspondence, programs, and clippings supplement the music manuscripts. The correspondence captures Fine's years of compositional growth while studying with Ruth Crawford (Seeger) and making acquaintances with figures such as Henry Cowell, George Antheil, Dane Rudhyar, and Aaron Copland.

arrangement.head: Organization of the Vivian Fine Music Manuscripts
arrangement.p: The Vivian Fine Music Manuscripts are organized in three series:
